en.sc1: We first examine the worst case cost.
en.sc2: The body of inssort contains two nested for loops.
en.sc3: The outer for loop is executed $n-1$ times.
en.sc4: The inner loop is harder to analyze since it depends on how many records in positions $0$ to $i-1$ have a value less than that of the record in position $i$.
en.sc5: Let's consider now a worst case example of an array with 6 elements. Since it is the worst case, each iteration of the outer loop does the greatest possible number of comparisons.
en.sc6: At $i=1$ a single comparison is required. We draw one box.
en.sc7: At $i=2$ two comparisons are required. We draw two boxes.
en.sc9: At $i=3$ three comparisons are required, so three boxes.
en.sc12: At $i=4$ four comparisons are required, so four boxes.
en.sc16: At $i=5$ five comparisons are required, so five boxes.
en.sc21: The total running time now will be the total surface area of this shape.
en.sc22_1: The total area will be the sum of the areas of the big traingle
en.sc23: So, the total area is $\frac{(n-1)(n-1)}{2} + \frac{(n-1)}{2}$ which gives $\frac{n(n-1)}{2}$.
en.sc24: Therefore, the worst case running time of insertion sort is $\theta(n^2)$.
